item.question: Which of the following BEST describes what the <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> directory is used for?
item.choice: When the system boots the contents of the <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> directory is read and depending on the runlevel the scripts are executed.
Each time a user logs in the contents of <font face="monospace">/etc/skel</font> is used to initialize the shell environment.
The contents of the directory can be used to provide a default environment when new users are created.
It contains the configuration files for the application <font face="monospace">skel</font>.
item.correct_answer: The contents of the directory can be used to provide a default environment when new users are created.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The network administrator provided you with a network range 192.168.0.32/26. You need two addresses for a router and DNS server. How many addresses are left for other hosts in the network?
item.hint: Within any network range the address with the host part all zero's or one's cannot be assigned to a network interface in the network. This means that two addresses in the range can not be used. The question states that two valid ip addresses are assigned to the router and a nameserver. Therefore, you will need to subtract 4 from the total amount of addresses in the range.

item.question: Which of the following is true for Open Source?
item.choice: The source code is freely available
You can do whatever you want with the source code and executables
item.correct_answer: The source code is freely available
item.hint: The term Open Source is a source of continuous debate. Fortunately, there is an Open Source Initiative that maintains the Open Source definition. You can find it at http://www.opensource.org/. One item of the definition is Free distribution, which means the source code must be freely available to anyone without requiring a fee. However, the distributor may ask for a fee to cover additional costs like bandwidth, storage media, etc. etc.

item.question: Which command will delete the environment variable <font face="monospace">EDITOR</font>?
item.hint: Redefining a variable with empty input will not remove the variable. Although most of the time the difference is not noticeable when the option <font face="monospace">-u</font> is set for Bash unset variables will invoke an error when they are expanded. Expansion is requested when you precede the variable name with a <font face="monospace">$</font>. Whenever you want to manipulate the actual variable you should use the variable name without preceding it with a <font face="monospace">$</font>.

item.question: You need to convert a textfile using the WINDOWS-1253 character encoding to UTF-8. Which of the following commands allows you to do this?
item.hint: You might be in doubt about <font face="monospace">convert</font>. However, the tool <font face="monospace">convert</font> is used to convert between image formats and not character encoding schemes.

item.question: Which of the following tools is used to configure CUPS?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: To get a list of all active network connections you issue the command?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command allows you to make a shell variable visible to subshells?
item.hint: If you want the shell to replace a variable with its contents you should precede it with a dollar sign ($). If you want to manipulate a variable you should only specify its name (without the <font face="monospace">$</font>). The command <font face="monospace">set</font> is used to configure the shell. Executing <font face="monospace">set</font> without arguments will print all defined variables. The command <font face="monospace">env</font> can be used to run a program in a modified environment. Running <font face="monospace">env</font> without any arguments will show the current environment. The command <font face="monospace">export</font> is a shell builtin to add variables for automatic inclusion to the enviroment of subsequently executed commands.

item.question:
Consider the following commandline:
What does the above commandline do?
item.choice: Syntax error as an opening bracket must be preceeded by an <font face="monospace">if</font>-keyword.
Execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> if it has execution permission set.
Check if <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> has execution permissions and if so will not execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font>
Simultaneously run two instances of <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font>
item.correct_answer: Execute <font face="monospace">/usr/bin/xterm</font> if it has execution permission set.
item.hint: The <font face="monospace">&&</font> is a logical AND which is evaluated in a lazy manner from left to right. This means that if the left program fails the next program or programs are not executed. The <font face="monospace">[</font> is an actual program that implements a test operation. It will stop with exit code 0 if the test passes and will return an exit code other than 0 if the test fails.

item.question: Which of the following are window managers? Choose all correct answers.
item.hint: Remember a window manager is not the same as a desktop manager. Although sometimes they are combined.

item.question: You discovered a pending job for the <font face="monospace">at</font>-command. Which of the following do you have to use to remove it?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following are mail transfer agents?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: A user calls and complains that he/she cannot work with the text-editor that is started when he/she wants to write an email using a text-oriented mailprogram like <font face="monospace">mutt</font> or <font face="monospace">pine</font>. Which file is best to edit to define a different default text-editor?
item.hint: The skel directory is only effective for new users. The question is about changing the pager for an existing user and only a single user. Therefore, it boils down to knowing the difference between <font face="monospace">.bashrc</font> and <font face="monospace">.bash_profile</font>.

item.question: A user calls claiming that the monitor does not work. You remember adding an extra network-card to her machine yesterday and did not test the new setup because of an urgent meeting. You have a feeling that the network card might be conflicting with the video-card. Which file would you check to see if there are any hardware address conflicts?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which option can you use to select a different UID instead of the default when using the command useradd?
Select all correct answers
item.hint: This one is nasty. The question asks you to select all correct answers. However, this does not mean there must be more than one correct answer.

item.question: Which three services are mapped to the TCP/IP ports 80, 53 and 22 (in the listed order)?
item.hint: As you are required to pick the answer that has all three in the correct order you may be able to answer this one correctly even if you do not know all portnumbers.

item.question: Which of the following is the best way to list all defined shell variables?
item.hint: Variables may or may not be included in a programs environment. You use the <font face="monospace">export</font> command to add a variable to the list of variables that should automatically be included in a programs environment.

item.question: Which of the following is the default <font face="monospace">Xorg</font> configuration file?
item.hint: This one is actually pretty easy if you think about it. There is only one choice that specifies the configuration file under <font face="monospace">/etc</font>. Because you know that the default location for configuration files is under <font face="monospace">/etc</font> (according to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard) your best bet would be that choice.

item.question: Which of the following protocols uses different network ports for data control and data transfer?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the purpose of the file <font face="monospace">xdm-config</font> for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>? (Choose the best answer)
item.choice: Mostly referencing other configuration files for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
It is a graphical tool to configure <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
item.correct_answer: Mostly referencing other configuration files for <font face="monospace">xdm</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can be used to add a new user on the server webserver?
item.hint: This question can be tricky if you do not know the answer directly. The reason is that it asks for adding a new user on a certain server. However, the server does not matter in this case. The question could just as easily be rephrased as follows: Which command can be used to add a new user?.

item.question: Your senior sysadmin created the script shown above to create a daily backup of the directory <font face="monospace">/data</font>. However, you notice that sometimes backups are missing. To check if the backup succeeded you want to extend the above script. Which of the following would sent an email showing the status of the backup and the date the backup was made.
item.hint: Using <font face="monospace">&&</font> and/or <font face="monospace">||</font> will only check the exit value of the previous command. Also note the usage of double and single quotes.

item.question: You need to change the toner in a printer. Which of the following utilities allows you to stop the printserver from sending new printjobs to the printer but keeps accepting new printjobs from clients?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which configuration file should be modified to change the action for the <font face="monospace">ctrl-alt-delete</font> key combination to something other than reboot?
item.hint: Two choices are bogus and you should be able to eliminate these rather quickly. You will be left with two options that both can be used to modify the system behavior when pression the <font face="monospace">ctrl-alt-delete</font> key combination. Fortunately, the question states you want to change the action to something other than rebooting. Changing the action using the online kernel parameter will not allow you to do anything other than reboot.

item.question: Which of the following lines from a <font face="monospace">syslog</font> configuration file would sent all log messages to the remote log server <font face="monospace">loggy.atcomputing.nl</font>
item.hint: Syslog uses facilities and priorities to differentiate log messages. The facility and priority are separated by a dot. Although there is not a general consensus on what to use for all, the asterisk (*) is often used to specify all. In computer science the @ symbol is often used to refer to a different host on a network.

item.question: Which entry in <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> is used to specify the location of the fonts for the X window system?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which switch or switches are used with the <font face="monospace">usermod</font> command to add the group <font face="monospace">user</font> to a user's secondary groups?
item.hint: The default behaviour of <font face="monospace">usermod</font> will be to override the current group memberships. You will need to tell it explicitly to append the group.

item.question: You want to convert the text-file <font face="monospace">guru.txt</font> to postscript to have it printed out later on. Which of the following commandlines would you use to accomplish this?
item.hint: Note that the question mentions you will be printing later on. Therefore, the correct answer only converts the file and does not print it as well.

item.question: Where is the queue directory for the CUPS system usually found? (provide the full directory-path)
item.hint: The default location for queues is under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>. In computer science, spool refers to the process of placing data in a temporary working area for another program to process. Each system that requires a spool creates its own directory under <font face="monospace">/var/spool</font>, usually named after the system that uses it.

item.question: You want the command <font face="monospace">atc2</font> only to be executed when the command <font face="monospace">atc1</font> fails. Which of the following command lines will allow this?
item.hint: <font face="monospace">&&</font> stands for AND. <font face="monospace">||</font> stands for OR. These are evaluated from left to right using lazy evaluation. This means that if evaluating the next condition does not matter for the overall result, the next condition or conditions will not be evaluated. If you use a logical OR the overall result will be true if at least one of the conditions is true. If you use a logical AND all conditions must be true to make the overall result become true. Therefore, if you use a logical OR and the left command fails the next command will be executed. If the left command succeeds there is no need to execute the next command. When using a logical AND the next command will only be executed if the left command succeeded.

item.question: In which of the following configuration files can you connect hostnames to ip-addresses?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You notice that a lot of users complain that reading manpages is very inconvenient and ask you if you can change the pager to use the command <font face="monospace">less</font> instead of <font face="monospace">more</font>. Which of the following files would you edit to make this change.
item.hint: The default pager can be set through the <font face="monospace">PAGER</font> variable. Therefore, you will need to find a way to set the <font face="monospace">PAGER</font> variable each time a user logs in and starts a shell. Also note that the skel directory is only effective for new users. The question is about changing the pager for current users as well.

item.question: Select the line that best represents the permissions for the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>.
item.hint: The file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> is used by many programs to locate the homedirectory of a user or get the username associated with a user ID. If permissions were to be too strict a lot of user friendliness would be disabled. For instance tilde substitution by the shell.

item.question: Which crontab entry is best used to set the system time at regular intervals?
item.hint: In this case the time specification in the crontab entries does not matter. There is only one choice with a correct command that will set the system time.

item.question: What file contains kernel level logging information such as output from a kernel module when it is loaded?
item.hint: The question does not state what flavour and in that case you should assume a default Debian or RedHat setup. Answers that apply to either one will be considered correct.

item.question: In which file can you specify default xterm geometry settings for a specific user?
item.hint: The X Display Manager uses multiple configuration files that start with a capital <font face="monospace">X</font>.

item.question: When using the command <font face="monospace">useradd</font> which option can be used to specify the user's home directory?
item.hint: The question is not about creating the user's homedirectory when adding a new user but specifying the location of the homedirectory.

item.question: Which of the following websites provide linux related news?
item.hint: You either know 'em or you don't. If you don't better check them out regularly to keep up to date.

item.question: You want to run <font face="monospace">logrotate</font> on a daily basis. What should you do to make this possible?
item.choice: Add or edit a configuration in <font face="monospace">/etc/logrotate.d</font>
Use the <font face="monospace">at</font> command to run <font face="monospace">logrotate</font> at a specific time
item.hint: Linux tries to keep to the principal small is beautiful. This is a design principle where each program does one thing and does it well. Therefore, logrotate will do only log rotation and there is a separate daemon to execute programs periodically.

item.question: Which file is used by TCP Wrapper to determine which connections should be denied for a network service? (Provide the full path)
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: During your monthly security audit on a RedHat system you want to check if any files from the package <font face="monospace">cups</font> have changed since installation. Which command with all needed options provides you with this information?
item.hint: What you are looking for is package verification, also known as verify...

item.question: You need to investigate which machine on your network fails to forward IP packets. Which command will be best to locate the machine?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: A user says she would like to use <font face="monospace">joe</font> as her default editor. Which of the following files would you edit to make sure the editor is always set as default when the user logs in?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: To synchronize the hardware clock with the system clock which command would you use?
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">date</font> will only set the system clock. The system clock is maintained by the kernel and may be out of sync with the hardware clock. Most Linux distributions will set the system clock equal to the hardware clock during system boot and vice versa during a shutdown.

item.question: Which of the following lines do you usually find at the beginning of a shell script?
item.hint: When you execute a shell script as a normal command the first line is used by the kernel to determine which interpreter must be started to actually read and execute the script. Therefore, the first line should point to the shell command. Now you only need to know if the magic key is just a hash or a hash bang...

item.question: Which command is used to view the queue for the <font face="monospace">at</font>-command?
item.hint: If not stated explicitly assume only the command name is required and not the path as well.

item.question: To let your NTP service synchronize with an external source you would modify the file?
item.hint: Most programs that use a configuration file under <font face="monospace">/etc</font> create a new directory usually naming it after the program. However, <font face="monospace">ntp</font> does not and places its configuration file directly under <font face="monospace">/etc</font>.

item.question: What best describes above statement?
item.choice: It will give an error as you can only select from one table at a time.

SELECT will delete all rows in the tables books and authors where
the id column in books matches the book_id column.
It will return only the columns <font face="monospace">title</font> and <font face="monospace">name</font> in the result.

It will select usage of the title and name on tables books and authors if and
only if the id equals book_id.
item.correct_answer: It will return only the columns <font face="monospace">title</font> and <font face="monospace">name</font> in the result.
item.hint: The statement comes from SQL. The SELECT will return rows FROM one or more tables using WHERE as a criterium.

item.question: Concerning the exit value of a command, which of the following is true?
item.choice: You can't test for normal execution by checking the exit value.
When the command failed execution the exit value will be 0.
When the command executed succesfully the exit value will be 0.
An exit value other than 0 will result in the shell being terminated.
item.correct_answer: When the command executed succesfully the exit value will be 0.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following shell variables specifies the Xorg server and screen that will be used by a graphical application?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: You are migrating the home directories to a new server. Which of the following commands allows you to create users and create the home directories only if they do not already exist?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: In the passwd file, you changed <font face="monospace">/bin/bash</font> to <font face="monospace">/bin/false</font> for user bob. What best describes the effect on bob's account?
item.choice: When bob logs in on a terminal screen he will immediately logout.
Bob will be asked to provide a new shell to use
item.correct_answer: When bob logs in on a terminal screen he will immediately logout.
item.hint: The default shell for a specific user is specified in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font>. The default shell specification should point to an executable that is started by a terminal when it needs to run a shell. The program <font face="monospace">/bin/false</font> will do nothing but exit with an exit code indicating a failure.

item.question: Which section in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/X11/xorg.conf</font> allows you to specify the video resolutions for specific colour depths?
item.hint: A single Xorg server can manage multiple screens on multiple monitors. For each screen you can specify the video resolution and colour depth.

item.question: You get a complaint that domainname <font face="monospace">www.atcomputing.nl</font> cannot be reached. Which tool would be best to check if a router is causing problems?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
The content of the file ~/myscript.sh is given in above exhibit.
What will be the output when you execute the following commandline?
~/myscript.sh i like penguins
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">shift</font> will shift all parameters one place to the left. Hence, <font face="monospace">$1</font> becomes <font face="monospace">$0</font>, <font face="monospace">$2</font> becomes <font face="monospace">$1</font>, etc. etc.

item.question: When installing the X Window System the monitor was not correctly detected. Fortunately you found the technical specifications of the monitor. Which <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> section would you edit to specify the correct values for the monitor?
item.hint: <font face="monospace">Modeline</font> is used in <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> to provide information about a certain monitor and how to set it to a specified resolution. However it is not a section in the <font face="monospace">xorg.conf</font> file. The section <font face="monospace">Screen</font> specifies the default color depth and resolution you want to set the monitor too. However, it does not specify the technical aspects of the monitor like refresh rate and display size.

item.question: What is the output when the above shell script executes?
item.choice: The contents of the file guru.
No output but a file named guru is created.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following IP networks does RFC 1918 reserve for use on private intranets?
item.hint: There are three such ranges. One is <font face="monospace">192.168.0.0/24</font> and another is <font face="monospace">172.16.0.0/12</font>. The third range is contains one of the ip adresses in the given choices.

item.question: Which of the following tools would you use to check if a remote system is correctly connected to a network on the network layer?
item.hint: DNS is at the application layer and not the network layer. A protocol that is at the network layer is the Internet Protocol (IP).

item.question: The correct command to view ALL line printer queues is?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.
